Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Plant-herbivore Interactions and Host Race Formation: Reconstructing the Evolution of Chrysochus-Apocynaceae Associations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The relationships between intercontinental dispersals and the evolution of host plant-herbivore interactions are not well understood, but may offer insight into invasive species ineractions. Two species of dogbane leaf beetles (Chrysochus, Chrysomelidae) possess an adaptation allowing them to feed on the toxic dogbane plants (Apocynum, Apocynaceae) in North America. Eight Chrysochus species live in Asia alongside Apocynum, but the nature of their interactions there, and when and how the association in North America evolved, is unknown. This project will investigate the evolution of the association between Chrysochus and Apocynaceae, focusing on the interactions between the widespread C. chinensis and its multiple hosts. Specimens of Chrysochus and their host plants will be collected in China to identify previously unknown host associations and create an evolutionary tree. Feeding experiments will be conducted on C. chinensis to determine whether separate populations eat different hosts, often an early step toward speciation. Experiments will be supervised by Dr. Huai-Jun Xue, associate professor at the Institute of Zoology (IOZ) in Beijing and expert on the evolution of insect-host plant specialization. Situated within the ranges of several Chrysochus species, the IOZ holds the largest collection of the beetles in Asia, making it the ideal location to investigate their evolution.

The award will be used to collect specimens of ten Chrysochus and Platycorynus (a closely related genus) species in five provinces in China. Host plants, other plants in the Apocynaceae, and observations of feeding behavior will be collected in those areas. This work will expand the host association information for the group, and DNA from field-collected and museum specimens will later be sequenced with high-throughput Illumina sequencing to construct the first molecular phylogeny of Chrysochus with complete sampling of species. C. chinensis individuals will be collected in Beijing and fed on several potential host plants in host acceptance and oviposition experiments. Their preference for, and fitness on, the potential hosts will be assessed by proxies such as growth and oviposition rates to determine whether there is evidence for the evolution of host races. This project will contribute to the field of plant-insect interactions, the natural history of an understudied group of organisms, and encourage future cooperation between the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University and the IOZ.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on exploring the specialist associations between "dogbane" and "milikweed" leaf beetles in the Corynodini tribe and their Asian host plants in the Apocynaceae (dogbane) family. In North America, the specialist host plant-insect herbivore interaction between Chrysochus beetles and their host plants is mediated by toxic cardenolides produced by the plants and counter-adaptations in the beetles. In order to understand the evolution of such an interaction, we need to know whether related beetles also feed on host plants with cardenolides and what their interspecies relationships are. The bulk of Corynodini is in Asia and the species and their host relationships are understudied. My research aims for this EAPSI fellowship were threefold: to (1) make observations of host associations and collect species of Corynodini across China for a phylogeny of the group, (2) conduct feeding experiments to determine whether Chrysochus chinensis populations near Beijing display signs of host race formation, and (3) survey the Corynodini specimens in the Institute of Zoology, CAS’s collections in Beijing.

During the course of the 2017 EAPSI program I travelled to eight cities in six different provinces of China to collect as many species of Corynodini as possible. I was able to collect Corynodini beetles in Hefei (Anhui), Guilin (Guangxi), Beijing, and Xishuangbanna (Yunnan), adding four species (Chrysochus chinensis, Platycorynus ignicollis, P. parryi, and P. peregrinus) to an eventual phylogeny of the group. Monsoon conditions and lack of host plants made collecting difficult in some areas. My field collection experiences confirmed previously reported hosts, in most cases, but also produced several never-before-recorded host plants in the case of Platycorynus peregrinus, one of which is not native to Asia and, reportedly, produces cardenolides. The beetle specimens collected are being sampled for a phylogeny via DNA isolation and next-generation sequencing. Vouchers of the host plants will be tested for secondary metabolite content.

In Beijing I collected populations of Chrysochus chinensis with my host advisor, Dr. Xue Huai-Jun, of the Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing. We looked for populations of this species feeding on different host plants, as it has at least 12 reported hosts in six different families, and tested for evidence of host races (a step on the way to speciation). We found populations feeding on three different Apocynaceae hosts. Feeding experiments with local non-Apocynaceae reported hosts demonstrated that those reports were false, and experiments with local Apocynaceae hosts demonstrated that, rather than displaying fidelity to their field host, all populations of C. chinensis strongly preferred Cynanchum thesioides. While in Beijing, I also examined the IOZ’s collection of Corynodini and recorded data on species, morphometrics, and collection locales.

My EAPSI project involved fieldwork in six different provinces and lab work in Beijing. As such, I relied on a great number of Chinese and foreign friends and collaborators, in addition to my host advisor and his graduate student mentee, Wei Jing, at the IOZ. Their help and advice made this work possible, and I intend to continue these valuable collaborations in the future. A paper is in progress on the results of the feeding experiments described above and results are also being disseminated in the form of public outreach events through Drexel University and presentations at upcoming international conferences.
